<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Litz Thomas.jpg|frame|right|Thomas Litz interviewed after a competition]] --> {{Infobox figure skater |name= Thomas Litz |image= |caption= |country= [[United States]] |fullname = |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1945|3|14}} |birth_place = |height= |coach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |formerchoreographer= |skating club= [[Hershey FSC]] |retired= |medaltemplates= <!-- see [[Template:MedalRelatedTemplates]] --> {{MedalCountry | [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[North American Figure Skating Championships|North American Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1963 North American Figure Skating Championships|1963 Vancouver]]|[[1963 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} }}
'''Thomas Litz''' (born March 14, 1945) is a former [[United States|American]] [[figure skater]]. He won the gold medal at the 1963 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] and competed at the 1964 [[Winter Olympics]]. Litz is credited as being the first skater to land the [[toe loop jump|triple toe loop jump]], a feat he accomplished at the 1964 [[World Figure Skating Championships]].
Litz was from [[Hershey, Pennsylvania]] and represented the Hershey Figure Skating Club. He was coached by [[Felix Kaspar]].<ref>[http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EBUrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i5wFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6324,5323169&dq=figure+skating&hl=en "Started Here"], ''The Reading Eagle'', Feb 12, 1963</ref>
He had to withdraw from the [[1963 World Figure Skating Championships]] (the year he won his national title) because of a sprained ankle.<ref>"1963 North American, U.S., & Canadian Champions", ''Skating'' magazine, May 1963</ref>
Litz coaches in [[Lake Placid, New York]].
